block.p: Your article on the glamorization of 14th Street [''On 14th Street, Less Grit, More Glamour,'' Aug. 13] errs in its assumption that the entire surrounding population is eagerly awaiting the purge that will force out gritty and inexpensive stores and usher in luxury apartments and national chains.

Like thousands of my neighbors in the Village and Chelsea -- from middle-class professionals struggling to stay in Manhattan to working-class residents of the projects in western Chelsea -- I depend on 14th Street as an affordable alternative in an area becoming overpriced and upscale to a fault.

I wish that an article on 14th Street would instead celebrate such existing businesses as the invaluable Western Beef, a friendly full-service discount supermarket where my family's weekly grocery bill is almost half what it would be at my local D'Agostino's.
